conclusion: The problem involves determining the internal resistance of a silicon photocell based on a given U-I graph.
Line a represents the U-I characteristic of a battery under a certain light intensity, and line b represents the U-I characteristic of a resistance R.
The open circuit voltage (Voc) is the voltage when no current is flowing, corresponding to the intersection of line a with the U-axis.
The short circuit current (Isc) is the current when the voltage is zero, corresponding to the intersection of line a with the I-axis.
The operating point is where the load line b intersects the battery's U-I curve a.
The operating point is at U = 2.5 V and I = 0.2 A.
The internal resistance (r) can be calculated using the formula r = (Uoc - U) / I.
Substitute the values from the operating point: r = (3.6 V - 2.5 V) / 0.2 A = 5.5 Ω.
The internal resistance of the silicon photocell is 5.5 Ω.
